Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Try `if request.form.get("character") == None:`, or `if not request.form.get("character"):`, or maybe `if not "character" in request.form:`. `.get("character")`, unlike `["character"]`, will not raise an error (you should see the error on your terminal), but return some default value instead, which is `None` if not specified otherwise.

Author: Brewslee#6566
Content: That solved it - thanks! Do you have any insights into why I was getting error 400 using request.form[ ]?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Your function crashed. You should have seen a stack trace on the terminal where you start the server.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: `[]` type access will raise an error if the key does not exist. The `.get()` type access returns a default value instead. With the `in` operator, you can check whether a key exists in a dict.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
```Python
my_dict = { "answer" : 42 }
print(my_dict["answer"]) # nothing special
print(my_dict.get("answer")) # same
print(my_dict.get("discordia")) # "discordia" is not a key in this dict, get returns the default None
print(my_dict.get("eris", 23))  # "eris" is also not a valid key, so get returns the value 23 instead
print("Borderline Cobblestone" in my_dict) # checks whether this key exists in the dict
print(my_dict["Bugglesome Counterwrench"]) # key is not valid, raises KeyError
```

Author: Brewslee#6566
Content: Ahh I get it now. In flask, request.data is a dict data type so accessing an absent key with [ ] returns an error whereas the .get() function will return None. So basically I was getting 400 because my code was trying to do something illegal. Thanks again @Blauelf!

A selector for a type, or a selector for a class, might return multiple elements (`querySelector` will return the first only, wile `querySelectorAll` returns... all of them). A selector for `id` won't refer to multiple elements, as IDs must be unique. You would find an element `<input type="text" name="username" id="username" placeholder="Your username">` (the `id` is relevant here) using `document.getElementById("username")` or `document.querySelector("#username")` (the hash is CSS for referring to an id).

And then there's also the form in the DOM, holding a list of all of its input elements. See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLFormElement#Usage_notes

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Flask expects your function to return a response object (or a string, in that case it would wrap it into a default response object). The response object has headers like the return code for redirect and the "location" header with the new location. So `redirect` does not perform the redirect, it simply creates an object that will cause Flask to issue the redirect when it is returned from a route.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
If a property does not exist at an object, it's searched through the prototype chain ("delegation"). For arrays, the next one would be `Array.prototype`, so when I say `arr.slice(3, 5)`, it will not have a "slice" property, but up the prototype chain it can be found at `Array.prototype`, so it's same as `Array.prototype.slice.call(arr, 3, 5)` (or closer to `slice.apply(arr, [3, 5])`, but that does not matter at all).

In Python, it's pretty similar, just completely different. Python does not clearly differentiate between static and member methods (does so implicitly via first parameter for methods which is named `self` by convention), and Python supports inheriting from multiple classes.
